content: Am I Addicted to Stardew Valley? I’m pixellating at the seams Sephy Hallow Blocked Unblock Follow Following Jul 13, 2018 Gameplay screenshots courtesy of author I am homesick for a country I can’t go back to. Between the throes of Brexit and the landslide of debt early repatriation would bury us in, I know I won’t be going home any time soon. For all its loveliness, Vancouver’s forest of glass towers will never feel like the woods and fields of England’s green and pleasant land. Although I have made new relationships, the established friends — some who I’ve known for more than 15 years — live just slightly too far in the future for a weekday Skype. Adventures have moments of isolation, and this is mine. Lately my evenings have been a fog of social media scrolling and YouTube comedy shorts, as a lethargic summer depression has settled in. My head has been too cloudy to write, and I haven’t mustered the motivation to exercise. This was my mindset when I decided to watch a James Veitch parody review of Stardew Valley. I don’t think Mr. Veitch meant to make an advert. The series highlights the absurdities of this strange pixel-art farming simulator, its small-town digital dramas over crop seasons, courtship, and village fetes. He points out how ridiculous it is for a farm to have its own theme song — and he’s right — but there was something so soothing about the music, so peaceful about the close-knit community and their hyper-local concerns. It was engaging enough to care about, but inconsequential if I gave up or fucked up. I had to play it. On Sunday afternoon, I parked myself in front of the PS4, expecting a couple of hours of distraction from the emotional anesthesia I’ve been living in. By 11 p.m., my arse was numb, but my mind was alive again. I could tell you there’s more to it than foraging and farming, but at its heart, Stardew Valley is a pleasantly simple game. Collect things, build them, foster relationships with non-player characters (NPCs). Watch the days whisk by, as every 10 seconds of real-world time translates into 10 minutes in the Valley. Each day, filled with its own small but satisfying challenges, is as fleeting as a passing cloud. After a few hours, I have seen two seasons bloom. When I sleep, I dream of empty fields. Time moves slowly in the real world. Monday crawls. I get home from work and sink back into the Valley. I resurface twice —once for a five-minute dinner interlude; once, a quick scramble for the controller charging cable. I don’t notice the sun setting (the sun in the real world). Engrossed, I forget the glass of iced tea my partner plonked right in front of me. I go to bed later than usual, but I can’t sleep. My head is a riot of ideas. Something about this game is awakening me from the coma of depression. J ohann Hari wrote about the misconceptions surrounding addiction some years back. He described his findings as a “radical assault” on common beliefs; it isn’t the substances alone that addict us, but their presence combined with our need for escape. He describes an experiment by Bruce Alexander, comparing the reactions of isolated rats to those housed in a community and supplied with a range of toys — a rodent paradise he named Rat Park. Both cages were rigged with drugged and clean water to choose from; but the residents of Rat Park reacted different than the isolated rats did. “The rats with good lives didn’t like the drugged water,” Hari writes. The drugs weren’t compelling enough on their own; it took a desperation for reprieve to instigate an addiction. It checks out: Returning Vietnam veterans had spent months surrounded by the horrors of war, often high; yet, when they returned home, not all of them continued to use. Those who found a stable home life waiting for them, or managed to create one, simply stopped using. As Hari states, “They shifted from a terrifying cage back to a pleasant one, so didn’t want the drug any more.” I have my own experience of addiction. My unhealthy relationship with alcohol started at 16. I couldn’t cope with the unpredictable outbursts of my mother’s PTSD, so I left. The next two years of unstable living were a mixed bag. I slept on the street at least once. I made lifelong friendships. I drank hard and laughed hard. For better or worse, I was never alone. Staying with other people — not having your own private space to retreat to — is like living in a fish bowl. You are always in “social mode”; you must be ready to engage with other humans at all times, in any space other than a bathroom. I was a teenager with a social anxiety disorder, stuck in a benevolent Panopticon . I drank to swallow the anxious buoy in my throat. It became my escape hatch for the better part of a decade. In December 2013, with a stable home life acting as a foundation, I gave up drinking. In November 2017, I uprooted myself from my support network and moved 5,000 miles away from home. The isolation has put me back in a terrifying cage. On Tuesday, I have a migraine. I close the blinds and, for a few hours, I forget where I am. I also forget to take the recycling down, but I catch two salmon in a Stardew river and feel satisfied that I have achieved something. Wednesday is my partner’s birthday. I squeeze in a couple of ‘Dew days before he gets home. We take a bus west for dinner at a sushi restaurant that feels more like an underwater rave, all UV lighting and papier-mâché angler fish bobbing on the ceiling. I sip a virgin mojito and wish we didn’t have to leave. Secretly, I want to make out in a dark corner until we melt into the background. We wait 40 minutes for the bus back. We bask in doing nothing. The sunset is warm and glowing, and the street is quiet. The real world feels so much more vivid today. Thursday is a blur. Pre-game, I swallow a yoghurt and scrawl a handful of notes on things I suddenly want to write, and it feels good. I don’t stop playing until 1 a.m., because I know I won’t sleep without learning the outcome of the grange competition at the Stardew Valley Fair. I crawl into bed next to my husband. I kiss his back, but he has been asleep for a while. Friday lunchtime, I scour YouTube for Stardew tips. It is nearly 30 degrees in Vancouver, but snow is settling on the farm. Nothing will grow until spring. The season’s powder blue palette is bewitching and hostile. I gaze into the weekend, its vast expanse of time calling me to plant and build and craft. I could take a mini-break in Stardew Valley. I could pass another year in 48 hours. My stomach flutters at the thought. My husband asks what I want to do. Outside, the sun sparkles over the mountains. Do I play or do I go?
title_html: Am I Addicted to Stardew Valley?
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • Hands
  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

Am I Addicted to Stardew Valley?

I’m pixellating at the seams

Sephy Hallow
Jul 13, 2018

I am homesick for a country I can’t go back to. Between the throes of Brexit and the landslide of debt early repatriation would bury us in, I know I won’t be going home any time soon. For all its loveliness, Vancouver’s forest of glass towers will never feel like the woods and fields of England’s green and pleasant land. Although I have made new relationships, the established friends — some who I’ve known for more than 15 years — live just slightly too far in the future for a weekday Skype.

Adventures have moments of isolation, and this is mine.

Lately my evenings have been a fog of social media scrolling and YouTube comedy shorts, as a lethargic summer depression has settled in. My head has been too cloudy to write, and I haven’t mustered the motivation to exercise. This was my mindset when I decided to watch a James Veitch parody review of Stardew Valley.

I don’t think Mr. Veitch meant to make an advert. The series highlights the absurdities of this strange pixel-art farming simulator, its small-town digital dramas over crop seasons, courtship, and village fetes. He points out how ridiculous it is for a farm to have its own theme song — and he’s right — but there was something so soothing about the music, so peaceful about the close-knit community and their hyper-local concerns. It was engaging enough to care about, but inconsequential if I gave up or fucked up.

I had to play it.

On Sunday afternoon, I parked myself in front of the PS4, expecting a couple of hours of distraction from the emotional anesthesia I’ve been living in. By 11 p.m., my arse was numb, but my mind was alive again.

I could tell you there’s more to it than foraging and farming, but at its heart, Stardew Valley is a pleasantly simple game. Collect things, build them, foster relationships with non-player characters (NPCs). Watch the days whisk by, as every 10 seconds of real-world time translates into 10 minutes in the Valley. Each day, filled with its own small but satisfying challenges, is as fleeting as a passing cloud. After a few hours, I have seen two seasons bloom. When I sleep, I dream of empty fields.

Time moves slowly in the real world. Monday crawls. I get home from work and sink back into the Valley. I resurface twice —once for a five-minute dinner interlude; once, a quick scramble for the controller charging cable. I don’t notice the sun setting (the sun in the real world). Engrossed, I forget the glass of iced tea my partner plonked right in front of me.

I go to bed later than usual, but I can’t sleep. My head is a riot of ideas. Something about this game is awakening me from the coma of depression.

Johann Hari wrote about the misconceptions surrounding addiction some years back. He described his findings as a “radical assault” on common beliefs; it isn’t the substances alone that addict us, but their presence combined with our need for escape.

He describes an experiment by Bruce Alexander, comparing the reactions of isolated rats to those housed in a community and supplied with a range of toys — a rodent paradise he named Rat Park. Both cages were rigged with drugged and clean water to choose from; but the residents of Rat Park reacted different than the isolated rats did.

“The rats with good lives didn’t like the drugged water,” Hari writes.

The drugs weren’t compelling enough on their own; it took a desperation for reprieve to instigate an addiction. It checks out: Returning Vietnam veterans had spent months surrounded by the horrors of war, often high; yet, when they returned home, not all of them continued to use. Those who found a stable home life waiting for them, or managed to create one, simply stopped using. As Hari states, “They shifted from a terrifying cage back to a pleasant one, so didn’t want the drug any more.”

I have my own experience of addiction. My unhealthy relationship with alcohol started at 16. I couldn’t cope with the unpredictable outbursts of my mother’s PTSD, so I left. The next two years of unstable living were a mixed bag. I slept on the street at least once. I made lifelong friendships. I drank hard and laughed hard. For better or worse, I was never alone.

Staying with other people — not having your own private space to retreat to — is like living in a fish bowl. You are always in “social mode”; you must be ready to engage with other humans at all times, in any space other than a bathroom. I was a teenager with a social anxiety disorder, stuck in a benevolent Panopticon. I drank to swallow the anxious buoy in my throat. It became my escape hatch for the better part of a decade.

In December 2013, with a stable home life acting as a foundation, I gave up drinking.

In November 2017, I uprooted myself from my support network and moved 5,000 miles away from home.

The isolation has put me back in a terrifying cage.

On Tuesday, I have a migraine. I close the blinds and, for a few hours, I forget where I am. I also forget to take the recycling down, but I catch two salmon in a Stardew river and feel satisfied that I have achieved something.

Wednesday is my partner’s birthday. I squeeze in a couple of ‘Dew days before he gets home. We take a bus west for dinner at a sushi restaurant that feels more like an underwater rave, all UV lighting and papier-mâché angler fish bobbing on the ceiling. I sip a virgin mojito and wish we didn’t have to leave. Secretly, I want to make out in a dark corner until we melt into the background.

We wait 40 minutes for the bus back. We bask in doing nothing. The sunset is warm and glowing, and the street is quiet. The real world feels so much more vivid today.

Thursday is a blur. Pre-game, I swallow a yoghurt and scrawl a handful of notes on things I suddenly want to write, and it feels good. I don’t stop playing until 1 a.m., because I know I won’t sleep without learning the outcome of the grange competition at the Stardew Valley Fair. I crawl into bed next to my husband. I kiss his back, but he has been asleep for a while.

Friday lunchtime, I scour YouTube for Stardew tips. It is nearly 30 degrees in Vancouver, but snow is settling on the farm. Nothing will grow until spring. The season’s powder blue palette is bewitching and hostile.

I gaze into the weekend, its vast expanse of time calling me to plant and build and craft. I could take a mini-break in Stardew Valley. I could pass another year in 48 hours. My stomach flutters at the thought.

My husband asks what I want to do. Outside, the sun sparkles over the mountains.

Do I play or do I go?

    British-born, Vancouver-based copywriter and storyteller. www.sephyhallow.com

title: Am I Addicted to Stardew Valley?

In December 2013, with a stable home life acting as a foundation, I gave up drinking.
